article.text: Suleiman, who was a close aid of former president Hosni Mubarak, did not receive enough signatures from one of the provinces. Electoral law in Egypt stipulates that candidates must get 30,000 signatures from all of Egypt's 27 provinces or support from a party represented in parliament. The Muslim Brotherhood said it will appeal the commission's decision, state-run MENA news agency reported. Islamists vs. secularists Saturday's decision came a day after thousands of Islamists rallied in the streets of Cairo against candidates from the ousted regime. Liberal and secular groups also do not wish to see the return of Mubarak-era figures, but they stayed away from Friday's protest. They have instead called a demonstration on April 20 to denounce what they see as Islamist monopolization of political life in the country since the revolt. The commission has also approved 13 candidates, including former Arab League chief Amr Moussa, moderate Islamist Abdel-Moneim Abolfotoh and former prime minister Ahmed Shafiq. The elections - the first since Mubarak was ousted - are scheduled for May 23-24. Syrian forces have bombarded Homs, breaking the cease-fire that has been in place since Thursday, monitors say. The claims come only hours before UN observers are due to arrive in the country. A prison in northwestern Pakistan was raided early Sunday morning by armed insurgents who were able to free 384 prisoners, including some who were militants. A military parade marking the centenary of Kim Il-Sung, the founding president of North Korea, was held in the capital, Pyongyang, on Sunday. Weekend matches in Italy's soccer leagues have been cancelled following the death of a Serie B player during a match on Saturday.
